ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class had recorded lectures plus weekly small-group chats with Professor Peterson, as well as a weekly discussion section.
Pre-recorded lectures plus an in-class element and discussion section
Two asynchronous lectures as well as a small group meeting once a week, and a discussion section.
once-a-week zoom meetings with Professor Peterson
Weekly discussion section and short meeting w/ prof
Small group discussions.
The class was a recorded lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I now have a much deeper and more nuanced understanding of the origin and early period of the United States, a greater awareness of the mythology around America and its inaccuracies. I also found it fascinating to understand the Constitution as a document specifically tailored to meet the concerns of 1780s US leadership, a fact which has led to issues arising as present-day concerns have diverged ever more from theirs.
I learned a lot more about the nuanced history of the US, especially in areas I've never considered before. Really informative!
legacy of colonialism, empire, & expansion
A more comprehensive understanding of American history!

I learned a great deal about the discovery of the Americas by European explorers. I also learned a lot about early colonial America. Specifically, the course helped paint a continuous picture of how the first exploration by Spanish explorers eventually led to British colonies and an independent America.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was a phenomenal course! Strengths include Professor Peterson's lectures and his insightful answering of student questions, as well as some really unusual and fascinating readings. Can't think of any real weaknesses.

Strengths: Loved the communication with Professor Peterson! Manageable papers.
Weaknesses: I think synchronous lectures would have worked better for this class.

The course covered an extreme amount of material and time - as a result, it was difficult to go in-depth. Professor Peterson did an excellent job with his recorded lectures and live weekly meetings, but sometimes it was hard to dig in to material when there was so much.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course adapted phenomenally to the pandemic-necessitated online format with its structure of prerecorded lectures plus smaller discussion groups.
Meetings with Professor Peterson made it easier to communicate any issues that sprung up due to COVID.
I thought the small group discussions were lovely and helpful!

The recorded lectures were good - the weekly meetings with Professor Peterson were nice, but should have been optional office hours. The effect was increasing our class time by 30 minutes which would have been fine if optional, but wasn't advertised.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Even if you have taken an advanced-level US history course in high school, this is a phenomenal course that looks much more in-depth and brings in plenty of original and unusual readings and perspectives. Highly recommend this for anyone interested in US history, politics, government, or more importantly for anyone who just wants to be a good citizen and understand how we arrived at many of the present-day dynamics within the US.

Definitely. This class is a good introduction to early American history, as it covers such a vast time period that you get a good taste of everything. Professor Peterson is awesome, and a great guy to know as the DUS of the department. I'd say for History majors and other majors, this course is a great survey course where you'll have interesting lectures and learn how to analyze primary source readings with a relatively low workload and chill section environment.
I would! I think it was a really interesting and new way to look at American History, one that I've never gotten anywhere else.
Yes!

I'm on the fence about recommending this course. I thought the material we covered (especially some of the readings) were fascinating and gave me new insights into American history. At the same time, the course had a midterm exam, midterm paper, final exam, and final paper -  a great deal of work. I think the course would benefit from a clearer idea of what it wants to be. If it's going to be a large survey course, skip the long papers, and have short two page ones with exams. If the course wants to be more about specific events in U.S. history, cut down the syllabus, lengthen the papers, and ditch the exams.
